column4: Feature Description
column5: Verification Goal

column4: Interrupt acknowledge is always a pulse
column5: assert that irq_ack is always a pulse
column9: TODO update to non-"_o" assertions, when it is fixed

column4:
Interrupt acknowledge is only asserted when a valid interrupt has been taken by the core.
This acknowledge is used to signal interrupts to the ISS to ensure that the proper MTVEC addressed is entered.
column5: irq_ack never asserted unless processor has taken an interrupt

column4: Interrupt acknowledge only asserted once per interrupt
column5: irq_ack only asserts once for an interrupt service period

column4: Interrupt valid ID matches the active interrupt during the cycle where interrupt acknowledge is asserted
column5: Ensure that irq_id is the active interrupt when irq_ack is asserted

column4: Interrupt valid ID during interrupt acknowledge is never a reserved interrupt [15,14,13,12,10,9,8,6,5,4,2,1,0]
column5: Assert irq_id is not a reserved valid when irq_ack is asserted
column9: TODO update to non-"_o" assertions, when it is fixed

column4: All interrupt lines are level-sensitive.
column5: All assertions and modeling of interrupts for checking assume no edges required to qualify an interrupt.

column4: NMI is not reported on irq_ack
column5: Check that after an NMI is triggered, if there is no other interrupt occuring, then there should be no irq_ack

column4: Every irq_ack must be followed by a corresponding rvfi_intr
column5: Check that whenever and irq_ack occurs, then the next rvfi retired instruction must have rvfi_intr high

column4: When multiple interrupts are enabled and pending, the highest-indexed interrupt will always win, with the exception of the timer [7], which is always lowest priority
column5: Model arbitration in an assertion to ensure priority

column4: An interrupt that is both pending and enabled shall be taken, unless if the core is in debug mode or is blocked by external interfaces (rvalid, fence_flush_ack, etc), and the taking happens within a fixed number of cycles
column5: Check that when conditions are right, then the interrupt gets taken within expected time

column4: When mip is already set when the interrupt is enabled, the trap occurs immediately.
column5:
Assert that no instruction is executed between the interrupt being enabled(CSR write or xRET) and the interrupt being taken. Ideally verify with Formal

NOTE: this feature is meant to cover the case which triggered the bug in github issue #325.

column4: MTVEC can be bootstrapped via mtvec_addr_i to an initial 32-bit value upon reset
column5: MTVEC can be programmed via the bootstrap without explicitly writing the CSR

column4: MTVEC can be programmed to any valid instruction address aligned to a 256-byte boundary
column5: Ensure that multiple MTVEC values are tested.

column4: Core jumps to PC at MTVEC directly when interrupted an MTVEC[0] == DIRECT (0)
column5: PC value upon taking interrupt when MTVEC[0] == 0 is {MTVEC[31:8], 8'h0}

column4: Core jumps to PC at MTVEC + interrupt*4 directly when interrupted an MTVEC[0] == VECTORED (1)
column5: PC value upon taking interrupt when MTVEC[0] == 1 is {MTVEC[31:8], 8'h0} * interrupt_cause * 4

column4: Nested ISRs may be supported by manually saving MEPC and MSTATUS, then re-enabling desired interrupts.
column5: Implement a nested ISR and ensure that manual save, restore of MSTATUS, MEPC work as intended.

column4: Nested interrupt can be re-interrupt by lower or higher priority
column5: Implement a nested ISR and ensure that manual save, restore of MSTATUS, MEPC work as intended.  Ensure that the nested interrupts come from both higher and/or lower priority interrupts.

column4: Nested interrupt will not be re-interrupted if MIE masks off an interrupt.
column5: Implement a nested ISR and ensure that manual save, restore of MSTATUS, MEPC work as intended.  Try to nest interrupts with masked interrupts via MIE, but ensure no interrupt taken.

column4: The hardware automatically disables interrupts upon entering an interrupt/exception handler.
column5: Trigger interrupt prior to handler re-enabling interrupts.

column4: Upon interrupt exit, MSTATUS.MIE must be restored with MSTATUS.MPIE
column5: Manipulate MPIE during an ISR and ensure that MSTATUS.MIE reflects this value after MRET instruction

column4: MPIE contains the previous machine interrupt enable value upon interrupt entry
column5: MPIE contains value of MSTATUS.MIE upon ISR entry

column4: Interrupts may never be taken if MSTATUS.MIE is cleared
column5: Upon each interrupt ISR entry MSTATUS.MIE must be asserted
column9: TODO update to non-"_o" assertions, when it is fixed

column4: MCAUSE exception code is never set to a reserved interrupt [15,14,13,12,10,9,8,6,5,4,2,1,0]
column5: MCAUSE exception code is never a reserved interrupt value
column9: TODO update to non-"_o" assertions, when it is fixed

column4: MCAUSE exception code is set to the active interrupt code
column5: MCAUSE is the active interrupt

column4: MCAUSE bit 31 is always set during ISR regardless of the active interrupt
column5: MCAUSE[31] is set in interrupt.

column4: When taking an interrupt, the current PC is saved in MEPC
column5: Ensure that MEPC in ISR is value of saved PC.

column4: MEPC can be altered during ISR
column5: Take an interrupt, change the MEPC to another PC value, and ensure that PC is used after MRET

column4: MEPC may capture a 16-bit aligned or 32-bit aligned instruction
column5: Check that compressed instructions and non-compressed instructions are being interrupted

column4: When an interrupt is asserted externally, the corresponding bit is MIP is asserted
column5: Ensure that MIP reflects irq_i inputs

column4: MIP bits corresponding to reserved interrupts are never asserted
column5: Assert that MIP bits on reserved interrupts are not asserted

column4: When an ISR is entered, the active interrupt must have the corresponding bit in MIE asserted
column5: Upon each interrupt ISR entry the active interrupt's MIE bit must be set

column4: Interrupts can be taken when MIE is asserted and irq_i is asserted
column5: For a disabled interrupt (via MIE) that is asserted, ensure the interrupt can be taken if MIE is written high

column4: MIE masking works as expected with all legal combinations of asserted bit
column5: All values of MIE are tested

column4: Both MSTATUS[MIE] and corresponding bit in MIE must be set to service an interrupt.
column5: Check permutations of MSTATUS[MIE] and MIE

column4: After reset, all interrupts are disabled.
column5: MSTATUS[MIE]=0 and MIE=0 after reset.

column4: Execution of WFI causes the core to stop
column5: In normal execution the core stop within a certain time period after execution.

column4: WFI entry causes the clock gate to be disabled
column5: The core is not clocked during WFI

column4: core_sleep_o output signal is only asserted during active WFI
column5: Assert the proper operation of core_sleep_o

column4: WFI is exitted and normal operation occurs if an enabled interrupt becomes pending
column5: WFI is exitted within a 40 free-running clcoks after a valid wakeup event

column4: WFI must exit if an enabled interrupt becomes pending even if the status MIE is disabled
column5: WFI exit occurs due to a pending enabled interrupts when MSTATUS.MIE == 0

column4: Ensure second WFI in a sequence waits after servicing first interrupt
column5: In embedded context WFI is used often, ensure that WFI can be re-entered ASAP after servicing a ISR for a previous WFI

column4: Any machine-mode interrupt can cause a WFI exit
column5: Exit interrupt coverage

column4: When an instruction is interrupted, it is killed, meaning that it has no side-effects: 1) load/store instructions don't reach the bus, 2) control transfer instructions don't jump, 3) CSRs don't get updated, 4) GPRs don't get updated
column5: Check that bus, jumps, and registers are unaffected by killed instructions

column4: rvfi_intr must be high on the first reported instruction after an interrupt is taken and the handler is being executed
column5: Check that when an interrupt is taken, when rvfi shows the first instruction of the handler retiring, then rvfi_intr is high

column4: rvfi_intr must be high on the first reported instruction after a synchronous is taken and the handler is being executed
column5: Check that after rvfi reports rvfi_trap, and if the next executed instruction is the handler (i.e. no debug entry etc), then rvfi_intr is high

column4: rvfi_intr CAN be high on the first instruction of debug entry if the entry was caused by external debug request or single stepping, and if it is then mepc shall have been updated correctly
column5: Check that when an interrupt has been acknowledged (and mepc updated), but debug entry intercepted the running of the interrupt handler, then rvfi_intr is high

column4: Whenever rvfi_intr is qualified by rvfi_valid and there is no explicit reason for it to be high, it shall be low
column5: Check that when there is no reason (no interrupt ack, no rvfi_trap, etc) then rvfi_intr doesn't give any false alarm

column4: rvfi_intr is a don't-care whenever rvfi_valid is low (this is true for all rvfi signals but is mentioned explicitly here for rvfi_intr)
column5: (We don't need to check the non-qualified don't-care values)

column4: When rvfi_pc_rdata doesn't match the previous instruction's rvfi_pc_wdata, then rvfi_intr must be high, or rvfi_dbg must be non-zero
column5: Check that either rvfi_intr or rvfi_dbg is always present whenever rvfi_pc_rdata doesn't match the previous rvfi_pc_wdata

column4: When reporting the first instruction of an interrupt handler, then rvfi_dbg must be zero
column5: Check that upon interrupt taken, when the first instruction of the handler is executed, then rvfi_dbg is zero

column4: All of the CSR features can be seen on the rvfi csr signals
column5: (As long as the rvfi csr interface is separately verified we don't need to verify anything extra here, but in theory all of the csr checks above could additionally be checked via the rvfi interface)

column4: Unlike exceptions, interrupts are not modelled as happening on the retired instructions, but rather between the one with rvfi_intr and the one before
column5: (Other items cover this in more specific detail)

column4: The instruction retired before the interrupt has none of the interrut-related side-effects, and the instruction retired after the interrupt does have the side-effects
column5: Check that when an instruction retires with rvfi_intr, then the previous retirement did not include any interrupt-related side-effects (unless that too had rvfi_intr high): pc, mstatus, mcause, mepc

column4: On the instruction that has rvfi_intr, the interrupt-related side-effects shall be visible: pc update (rvfi_pc_rdata), csr updates (rvfi_csr_*_rmask, rvfi_csr_*_rdata)
column5: Check that when an instruction retires with rvfi_intr, then it does include interrupt-related side-effects: pc, mstatus, mcause, mepc

column4: For rvfi_intr, NMIs counts just like normal interrupts
column5: Check that after triggering an NMI then rvfi_intr becomes high

column3: Never masked by interrupt enable bits
column4: Neither shall the state of the mstatus.MIE bit nor shall the mie register stop an NMI from taking effect
column5: For all values of {mstatus.MIE, mie(all ones/zeros)}, check that triggering an NMI works the same

column4: While in debug mode, then NMIs are masked and aren't taken
column5: Check that an NMI triggering while in debug mode does not immediately jump to the debug handler with corresponding side-effects

column3: Masked by single stepping with stepie=0
column4: While single stepping with stepie=0, then NMIs are masked and aren't taken
column5: Check that an NMI triggering while single stepping with stepie=0 does not immediately jump to the debug handler with corresponding side-effects

column4: Unlike normal interrupts which are disabled at reset, NMIs cannot be disabled, so it is possible to trigger an NMI on the very first instruction
column5: Trigger an NMI as the very first executed instruction and see that the NMI is taken

column4: When an NMI is detected the core jumps immediately to nmi_addr_i
column5: Check that the core starts executing at PC=nmi_addr_i when an NMI is taken

column4: After the core has been enabled with fetch_enable_i, then nmi_addr_i cannot change
column5: Check that nmi_addr_i never changes value after fetch_enable_i has risen (this will verify the verification environment more than the core)

column4: nmi_addr_i must be word aligned
column5: Check that nmi_addr_i is always word aligned (this will verify the verification environment more than the core)

column4: dcsr.nmip shall indicate if an NMI is pending or not
column5: Check that when an NMI is pending then dcsr.nmip reads as 1, and vice versa when no NMI is pending

column4: The dcsr.nmip bit should work whether in debug mode or not
column5: Have an assertion cover statement check that nmip can get asserted while in debug mode, and another for nmip getting asserted while not in debug mode

column4: mepc is updated with the next instruction that was about to be executed when the NMI was taken
column5: Check that when taking an NMI then mepc gets updated correctly

column4: mcause is updated with the right exception code (128 load, 129 store)
column5: Check that when taking an NMI then mcause gets updated correctly

column4: When entering an interrupt handler, hardware disables interrupts globally, and this should also hold for NMIs
column5: Check that when an NMIs handler starts executing, then mstatus.mie is disabled

column4: When entering an interrupt handler, as hardware disables interrupts globally it must also save the previous setting in MPIE
column5: Check that when an NMIs handler starts executing, then mstatus.mpie get set to the previous mstatus.mie

column4: Store bus fault has the highest priority, then load bus fault, then all the other interrupts with their respective priorities
column5: Check that when load bus fault occur at the same time as a normal interrupt then the NMI gets priority. Check that when store bus fault occur at the same time as a normal interrupt then the NMI gets priority. Check that when load bus fault occur at the same time as a store bus fault then the store NMI gets priority.

column4: An NMI shall be taken, unless if the core is in debug mode or is blocked by external interfaces (rvalid, fence_flush_ack, etc), and the taking happens within a fixed number of cycles
column5: Check that when conditions are right, then the NMI gets taken within expected time
